document.docAuthor: Chemyreva, Vasilisa G. & Kolyada, Victor A.
document.masterDocTitle: Review of the genus Paramesius Westwood, 1832 (Hymenoptera: Diapriidae, Spilomicrini) from Russia, with description of four new species

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Review of the genus Paramesius Westwood, 1832 (Hymenoptera: Diapriidae, Spilomicrini) from Russia, with description of four new species

Spilomicrus minor

Spilomicrus striatifoveatus
Szabo, 1960 : 364
, s yn. nov.

subSubSection.paragraph: Diagnosis. Body length 1.4–2.8 mm ; pronotal cervical area poorly pubescent with a few long setae (Fig. 26); neck bare; pleurostoma with semicircular blade anteriorly near base of mandibula (Fig. 24); notauli almost full (Fig. 25) to shallow anteriorly; mesoscutal suprahumeral sulcus absent (Fig. 24); female A 12 in dorsal view elongate; petiole of male long 0.40–0.45 times as long as T2.

Variation . Notauli almost full to extending 0.65 of mesonotum length (Figs 23, 25, 26). Female. Body length 1.9–2.8 mm . Wings 0.64–0.87 times as long as body. A9–A12 subquadrate to distinctly elongate; A1– A7 yellow to brown. Petiole 0.25–0.32 times as long as T2. Anterior scutellar pit with 2–4 carinae. Male. Body length 1.4–2.6 mm . A1–A12 yellow to brown; A2–A4 same color with A1 or A1 distinctly paler; A4 with keel extending to 0.46–0.53 of A4 length. Anterior scutellar pit with 2–5 carinae.

Material examined.
Syntype : ( MNHN ) labelled “Belyta ♀ / rufipes nob”, “Muséum Paris/ France Merid./ Boyer de Fonscolombe ”, “Teleas/ rufipes Fonsc. / Holotype / 1832”
.
Syntype : ( MNHN ) labelled “ Paramesius / bifoveata”, “ ♂ ”, “Bitche”, “ Holotype ”, “Muséum Paris/ 1957/ coll. Kieffer ”
.
Holotype : ♀ ( HNHM ) labelled “ Spilomicrus / striatiformes/ Szabo”, “Szigetmonostor/ 1959.
VI.19.
”, ”Ounagaton/ Zoldarkor”, ”Legiti/ J.B. Szabo ”, “ Holotypus ♀ / Spilomicrus / striatifoveatus/ Szabo 1960 ”, ”Hym.Typ.No. 9584/ Mus. Budapest”
.

Distribution. *Abkhazia, Austria , Czech Republic , France (Bitche), Hungary , * Georgia , Germany , Moldova , Poland , Russia (European part and *Siberia), Slovakia , Sweden , Switzerland , but the species certainly distributed all over Europe.
